body:
ðŸ‘ tuning it down to `LOG.DEBUG`

First thing in an IDE launch is, I always mute it via `org.junit.level=WARNING` in a `logging.properties`.

The rationale for having it at `INFO` level is that it helps us to better assist users who are trying out the JUnit Platform for the first time.

For example, from that information alone we are immediately able to discern whether or not the user has the classpath configured correctly (e.g., hasn't forgotten to include the JUpiter or Vintage `TestEngine` as a dependency).

So I'm personally inclined to leave it as `INFO` for now, but I'm also open for switching to `DEBUG` if there is sufficient interest from the community in doing so.

rename.to: Reduce log level for detected test engines to DEBUG

body: I think it might make sense to disable logging by default and provide a simple way (e.g. by setting a system property) to enable it that we could document in the user guide.

> I think it might make sense to disable logging by default and provide a simple way (e.g. by setting a system property) to enable it that we could document in the user guide.

If we go that route, I think we'd need to introduce our own custom logging faÃ§ade to hide that additional level of indirection. Otherwise, everywhere we use logging will need to be modified with additional conditional checks. So I'm not really a fan of that... unless there is some feature of JUL that I'm unaware of which simplifies matters.

IMHO, I think it's a good idea to have logging enabled by default. Otherwise, users wouldn't even be informed of warnings or true errors.

So, introducing a "no INFO level logging" policy is perhaps not such a bad idea for a testing framework.
Reducing logging level from `INFO` to `Level.`[CONFIG](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/logging/Level.html#CONFIG) should be enough.

We could go for one of the proposed solutions in [this StackOverflow post](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2533227/how-can-i-disable-the-default-console-handler-while-using-the-java-logging-api) to disable logging of `org.junit` completely unless e.g. a system property is set.

issue.title: Log version numbers with discovered engines

milestone.title: 5.0 M4
milestone.description: Themes: test templates, repeated tests, and parameterized tests.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
There have been several instance where users ended up with mismatched versions of the JUnit 5 artifacts, such as #586.  Debugging these problems would be easier if the INFO-level log message also printed out the version number of the engine.  So this message:

```
INFO: Discovered TestEngines with IDs: [junit-jupiter]
```

Would become:

```
INFO: Discovered TestEngines with IDs: [junit-jupiter-5.0.0-SNAPSHOT]
```

Note that the engine name can remain a constant but the version could be pulled programmatically from the JAR's manifest file.

body: I'm still convinced, that `LOG.debug()` (or `LOG.config()`) is sufficient when detecting available test engines. As long as the "no engines found" case yields a `LOG.error()` or an exception to be thrown, everything's fine.

>   If we go that route, I think we'd need to introduce our own custom logging faÃ§ade to hide that additional level of indirection.

I know you avoid having additional dependencies in JUnit but if you use the slf4j-api, those who want to enable logging can do so just by putting an implementation on their classpath.  Otherwise the NOP implementation will eat the output.

> I know you avoid having additional dependencies

Period. ;-)

It's only a single logger usage (out of 19 in total) within the entire JUnit 5 sources that is a bit ... loud.

issue.title: Reduce log level for detected test engines

milestone.title: 5.0 M4
milestone.description: Themes: test templates, repeated tests, and parameterized tests.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Fixes #513 by using log level CONFIG instead of DEBUG.

If you want to see the information which engines were detected, use "-Djava.util.logging.config.file=LOG" with the content of LOG something similar to:

```
  handlers=java.util.logging.ConsoleHandler
  java.util.logging.ConsoleHandler.level=CONFIG
  org.junit.level=CONFIG
```

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the JUnit Contributor License Agreement.

body:
>> I know you avoid having additional dependencies

> Period. ;-)

To advertise Java 9 a little more, have a look at [redirected platform logging](https://www.sitepoint.com/ultimate-guide-to-java-9/#redirectedplatformlogging). :smiley:
How would that help us? As far as I could see from skimming the project description, that JEP only takes care of redirecting Platform Logging, not JUL, right?

(I didn't check whether JUL uses the new approach but wrote my previous and this comment under the assumption that it doesn't.)

JUnit could build on the new infrastructure and use `LoggerFinder` to get `Logger` instances, piping all messages through them. End users can then use the platform-logging-log4j2-bridge (once it exists; or whatever logging framework they prefer) to get those messages out.

Since JUnit 5 is surely going to target Java 8, more indirection is needed, though. JUnit would need its own logger interface and via multi-release JARs that could either be backed by JUL (in Java 8) or `LoggerFinder` (Java 9). Quite a lot of complexity...

Before thinking of designing and implementing a logging facade in JUnit 5, I'm preferring Marcs' simple proposal:
> We could go for one of the proposed solutions in this StackOverflow post to disable logging of org.junit completely unless e.g. a system property is set.

...more and more. The commit https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/commit/ddcfb41b0f824cdbaae7cf868d3491e555ced4f6 already made me circumvent the there in muted log level change by configuring the JUL facility via a custom JVM switch **and** an extra property file. Which felt and still feels awful.

A simple `-Djunit.debug=true` (checked via [Boolean.getBoolean()](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/Boolean.html#getBoolean-java.lang.String-)) that guards all (read: one) INFO level logging statements would render the properties file superfluous. If the debug switch is set to false (which it is by default) the logging statement is still emitted at CONFIG or FINE level.

Edit: With such an "enable INFO-level logging JUnit Platform/Jupiter switch" we could raise existing or even introduce a few more statements, that log for example the registered extensions, listeners (...) next to the registered engines.

issue.title: `MalformedParametersException` on JDK 8 for synthetic bridge methods in Jupiter classes (5.11.0-M1)

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
When using JDK 8 and `junit-jupiter-engine-5.11.0-M1`:
`MalformedParametersException` is thrown when calling `java.lang.reflect.Method#getParameters()` on some synthetic bridge methods.

Concerns version 5.11.0-M1 only: doesn't occur with 5.10.2 and older releases of "junit-jupiter-engine".

Also it only happens when using JDK-8:

- Java               : 1.8
- JVM vendor name    : Private Build
- JVM vendor version : 25.402-b06
- JVM name           : OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM
- JVM version        : 1.8.0_402-8u402-ga-2ubuntu1~22.04-b06
- JVM info           : mixed mode
- OS name            : Linux
- OS version         : 6.5.0-28-generic

This only concerns JDK 8. Everything seems to work just fine with later JDKs (e.g. 11, 17, 21).

There is something about how `junit-jupiter-engine-5.11.0-M1` was compiled that makes it not fully compatible with JDK 8.

## Steps to reproduce

Output from this program pinpoints the root problem:

```java
import java.lang.reflect.MalformedParametersException;
import java.lang.reflect.Method;
import java.util.*;
import org.junit.jupiter.engine.descriptor.*;
import org.junit.platform.engine.support.hierarchical.EngineExecutionContext;

class MalformedParametersException_forJupiterSyntheticNodeMethodImplementations_onlyOnJdk8 {
    public static void main(String[] ___) {
        System.out.println("\nRunning on " + System.getProperty("java.version") + " ...");

        java.util.stream.Stream.of(
                JupiterTestDescriptor.class, ClassBasedTestDescriptor.class,
                ClassTestDescriptor.class, MethodBasedTestDescriptor.class,
                TestMethodTestDescriptor.class, TestTemplateTestDescriptor.class,
                TestTemplateInvocationTestDescriptor.class,
                TestFactoryTestDescriptor.class, NestedClassTestDescriptor.class)

                .forEach(descriptorClass -> {

            Set<String> reasonsForMalformedParameters = new HashSet<>();
            StringBuilder methodsWithMalformedParameters = new StringBuilder();
            for (Method m : descriptorClass.getDeclaredMethods()) {
                try {
                    m.getParameters();

                } catch (MalformedParametersException badParameters) {
                    assert m.isSynthetic();
                    assert m.getParameterTypes()[0] == EngineExecutionContext.class;
                    reasonsForMalformedParameters.add(badParameters.getMessage());
                    methodsWithMalformedParameters.append("\n ->").append(m
                            .toString().substring("public".length())
                            .replaceAll("(?<=[ ,(])[a-zA-Z\\.]*\\.", " ")
                            .replaceFirst(" throws .++", ""));
                }
            }
            if (false == reasonsForMalformedParameters.isEmpty()) {
                System.out.println("\n" + reasonsForMalformedParameters
                        + " was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on "
                        + descriptorClass.getSimpleName() + ":" + methodsWithMalformedParameters);
            }
        });
    }
}
```

Running the above program on my laptop, using JDK 8 and `junit-jupiter-engine-5.11.0-M1`, results in this output:

```
Running on 1.8.0_402 ...

[Invalid parameter name ""] was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on JupiterTestDescriptor:
 ->  Node$SkipResult  shouldBeSkipped( EngineExecutionContext)
 -> void  cleanUp( EngineExecutionContext)
 ->  EngineExecutionContext  prepare( EngineExecutionContext)

[Invalid parameter name ""] was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on ClassBasedTestDescriptor:
 ->  EngineExecutionContext  prepare( EngineExecutionContext)
 ->  EngineExecutionContext  before( EngineExecutionContext)
 -> void  after( EngineExecutionContext)

[Invalid parameter name ""] was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on MethodBasedTestDescriptor:
 -> void  nodeSkipped( EngineExecutionContext, TestDescriptor, Node$SkipResult)

[Invalid parameter name ""] was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on TestMethodTestDescriptor:
 -> void  cleanUp( EngineExecutionContext)
 -> void  nodeFinished( EngineExecutionContext, TestDescriptor, TestExecutionResult)
 ->  EngineExecutionContext  execute( EngineExecutionContext, Node$DynamicTestExecutor)
 ->  EngineExecutionContext  prepare( EngineExecutionContext)

[Invalid parameter name ""] was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on TestTemplateTestDescriptor:
 ->  EngineExecutionContext  execute( EngineExecutionContext, Node$DynamicTestExecutor)
 ->  EngineExecutionContext  prepare( EngineExecutionContext)

[Invalid parameter name ""] was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on TestTemplateInvocationTestDescriptor:
 -> void  after( EngineExecutionContext)

[Invalid parameter name ""] was thrown for synthetic bridge methods on TestFactoryTestDescriptor:
 -> void  nodeSkipped( EngineExecutionContext, TestDescriptor, Node$SkipResult)
 -> void  nodeFinished( EngineExecutionContext, TestDescriptor, TestExecutionResult)
```

The above pinpoints a root problem that is far away from regular developer concerns, but it causes other indirect problems further down the road. E.g. using Mockito 4.11's `inline-mockmaker` to mock the above classes (on JDK 8) is problematic: "Mockito cannot mock this class: ...".

But test descriptor classes that don't have these synthetic bridge methods (e.g. `ClassTestDescriptor` and `NestedClassTestDescriptor`) are perfectly mockable.

## Context

Above program was run with these jars on classpath:

  - junit-jupiter-engine-5.11.0-M1.jar
  - unit-platform-engine-1.11.0-M1.jar
  - junit-platform-commons-1.11.0-M1.jar
  - junit-jupiter-api-5.11.0-M1.jar

JDK details:

- Java               : 1.8
- JVM vendor name    : Private Build
- JVM vendor version : 25.402-b06
- JVM name           : OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM
- JVM version        : 1.8.0_402-8u402-ga-2ubuntu1~22.04-b06
- JVM info           : mixed mode
- OS name            : Linux
- OS version         : 6.5.0-28-generic

This issue report only concerns classes of `junit-jupiter-engine-5.11.0-M1.jar`, but there is reason to suspect similar situation with other 5.11.0-M1 artifacts wherever there are synthetic bridge methods.
